This love letter to the 80's not only has a bombastic synthwave soundtrack, it lives and breathes it: dark humor sci-fi that laughs at the absolute carnage that a mechanized war machine can wreak upon densely populated urban areas. Story is lacking, but this game makes up for it in style and gameplay. 

While the campaign at first shoehorns you into only one loadout per mission, it branches out about 40% of the way through to allow you 3-4 different loadouts per level, each one changing the way you play drastically, from taking and dishing out massive ordnances, to hit-and-run tactics.

The game is best in the former as you're likely to get swarmed by large numbers of enemies. It never gets tiring firing a 140mm cannon into a large group of enemies. The visual feedback in this game is phenomenal. 

As to what I didn't enjoy, the isometric angle also makes it difficult to tell exactly where your shot will land, leading to plenty of missed shots. 

The limited ammo system can be hit-or-miss. It adds a lot of tension as you often have to pick your shots instead of simply spraying everywhere, which is a plus. However, if there are no enemy ammo drops to be had, your only recourse is to reload at ammo dumps. 

This is no fun at all given that it has to be the RIGHT type of ammo dump, often ALL the way on the other side of the map AND it is easily blown up AND it has limited ammo. Even less fun if you have a slow, lumbering vehicle and there are a million obstacles in the way. Running out of ammo happened more often that I would have liked, and I feel I was already playing conservatively when possible. 

Thankfully, there is a built-in infinite ammo cheat easily accessible through the developer console via F1. So these negatives are moot depending on how you want to play this game (namely if you just want to blow stuff up). Even then, these negatives largely don't get in the way of the mountain of fun to be had.

37871512.review:
In short Brigador is a fantastic game that's niche enough that it isn't for everyone.  If you're interested in driving stompy robots buy Bragador.  If you like isometric shooters buy Bragador. If you like challenging yourself buy Bragador.   If none of those things are true or you want something casual to spend your time on there are better choices.  

Now for the long version.  Brigador is an isometric vehicle shooter with both a campaign and freelance mode.  Either pays out money on successful mission completion which you use to unlock vehicles, weapons, special abilities, freelance missions, and lore.  The learning curve is relatively steep but managable, the tutorial missions at the start of the campaign are decent enough to learn the ropes.  The game can be quite difficult but that difficulty is always fair.  

Campaign mode have fixed enemy spawns and a selection of 4 loadouts to bring to that mission.  Difficulty of campaign missions mostly ramps up with earlier missions being much easier and later missions being harder.  There is one curveball mission in the middle which probably rage inducing for some. The loadouts for each campaign mission tend to have a mix of reasonable and challenge loadouts.  

Freelance mode is the meat of the game.  In it you choose a pilot which replaces the difficulty slider found in most games.  From there you select a vehicle, 2 weapons, special ability, and mission.  Freelance missions range from 2 maps to 30+ maps.  Individual maps have fixed layouts and psuedorandom enemy spawns.  Depending on the pilot, vehicle, and mission choices difficulty can range from cakewalk to 'I'm a skeleton in a golf cart, today the enemies will probably be exploding me for a change.' 

Weapons range from a lowly peashooter machine gun to city block leveling artillery with a huge range of weapons in between.  Almost every weapon has a niche that needs to be considered when choosing your loadout.  

Vehicles range from heavily armed nigh invincible supertanks to fast and agile but fragile agravs.   And a golf cart.  

All of the choices available for for freelance give a ton of replayability.  Different vehicles give a ton of variety, a Lowmill plays nothing like a Hoker.  Even within a vehicle different loadouts can play very differently, a Raider with Kraken, Pinch, and smoke, plays very differently from a Raider with Harvester, Donkey, and camo. 

Lorewise the game is set on a dystopian colony world far distant from earth.  The lore entries, pilot descriptions, and weapon descriptions are all written from the perspective of characters in the universe.  Each has their biases and knowledge gaps.  Personally I've found the writing to be uniformly excellent.  It's one of the better crafted worlds I've come across in a game, to the extent that when a new patch comes out the first thing I check is to see if there are new lore entries to unlock.  

If the above sounds interesting buy Brigador it will be worth every penny once you have an idea what you're doing.

37860594.review:
Brigador feels like a game that I missed in... 1995. A game where deaths feel like a collection of mistakes I can remember, not a game mechanic working against me. The music is great. The aestetic and graphics are great. The gameplay is great.


Brigador is a game that has been lovingly crafted, and I do mean that. Looking at the game while it's running (in a high resolution anyway) may not key you in on how it's doing what it does, but the game is entirely 2D. Even with the massive amount of rendering space on screen at once on my 1920x1200 monitor, the game still runs over 200FPS, and never drops. It's not an unoptimized mess, and it still manages to have a lot of pretty features for those who want the most to look at out of their game (The aiming path is rendered to make the 2D look 3D, and there is a lot of dynamic lighting to do the same).

With Brigador's Campaign mode you'll have most of the game's learning curve explained to get you on to a plain where you may start to use any of the vehicles, weapons and defences you purchase effectively. The first 12 missions aid you in controlling a Mech, a Tank and an Agrav (Anti-Gravity, or [i]hovertank[/i], if you will). Controls are currently available to split between Agravs between Mechs and Tanks, and while some people want a unique control preset between Mechs and Tanks, if you aren't bothered by the same control scheme on both, you won't need to change it every time you want to use one or the other. Controls are available between forward being [b]Tile Absolute:[/b] north on the map (North being selectable as top left or top right), [b]Screen Absolute:[/b] north on the screen (always up, you control 45 degrees against the map's grid), and [b]Relative:[/b] forward is forward to the vehicle's heading (allowing you to hold W and D to walk in circles). Agrav controls are mostly the same except for [b]Relative[/b], where W will move the vehicle towards the cursor. Pressing A and D will still strafe relative to the vehicle's heading. This occurs mainly because a mech has heading of the legs, and the turret. The legs move, the turret does not. A tank has the heading of the treads and the turret. The treads move, the turret does not. An Agrav has the heading of a turret. The turret moves. If you've played Hotline Miami or are used to the way it handles movement, an Agrav might not feel too far off when played in [b]Screen Absolute[/b] mode. There are a few options for control toggles: mech crouching, orientation lock, and Agrav low-fly height. Players may also change gamespeed (the default is 80, and the slider goes up to 100, or down to 50); the ingame loadingscreen hints recommend changing it down "if you use a controller or like seeing stuff explode in slow motion." I personally have left it at 80, but allowing people to change it is definitely a plus. Too bad you can't set it to 150% and play [i][b]Super Brigador Up-Armoured Turbo: Hyper Armored Combat[/b][/i].

The music is quite enjoyable, and I'd recommend the Deluxe edition from the start to save you a dollar (or two, depending on your currency) to get it's soundtrack (The Deluxe edition comes with an audio book and the soundtrack in MP3.) So far, my only complaint with the entire game is that the soundtrack isn't administered in FLAC. That's pretty impressive when you consider that I have no other problems.

Do I think Brigador is worth your time? Absolutely. Brigador's gameplay allows you to jump in at just about any time after you've made some bank to choose what pilot, vehicle, weapons and defences you want and then a set of zones to just play whenever. Pilots dictate the game's difficulty and additional victory cash rewards, with some pilots ranging from easier difficulties, to a pilot who's difficulty is at max on the first map you will load on (each pilot has a Bio, and visible stats for difficulty and payout bonuses, regardless of wether you've bought them using ingame currency. There are no loot boxes, and no way to use real world money to get anything in this game).


[b]tl;dr:[/b] Brigador, post Up-Armored relaunch, is quite possibly the second best game of 2016 to me, second only to Titanfall 2. It is well worth your time and money.

Awesome graphics, if you're a fan of the sprite style.  Everything is so detailed, all the buildings, mechs, enemies, piles of rubble you leave behind and even the little civvies running around.  The lighting is great too.  The flash from the various guns and lasers, all the neon lighting around, and the frantic little flashlights that kick in when you scare the civilians.  It also interacts with the environment really well, the shadows from your vehicles lights look awesome on the rubble and grass and stuff.

Sound and music are great.  Guns, vehicles and explosions sound very powerful and punchy, the audio helps everything feel like it has weight to it.

Everything is destructible.  For me this is more about seeing shit blow up in a battle than necessarily pathing through structures, which is slow and loud (but still fun)



The vehicles have 3 types, mechs, tanks, and anti-grav vehicles.  Within those three categories, there are a variety of sizes, with differing stats, weapon mount types and difficulty multipliers (more on that in a bit)

There are 3 factions that each have vehicles in those three styles.
Each faction has visual differences and, if I remember right, faction specific stat tweaks.  Nothing game-changing, but one faction may favor shields over hull strength for instance.

Each vehicle has a certain amount of hull strength, shields, and overcharge shield capacity.  Hull strength is just your hitpoints, can't remember if there's any way to replenish it (I don't think so).  Shields can be replenished, though they won't do it passively over time, but from pickups from destroyed enemies.  And overcharge is bonus shield capacity that deteriorates over time.

Each vehicle has two weapon mounts, from types like auxiliary, main, heavy, small (and a few others I think), that determines what guns you get to pick from for your loadout.



For weapons there are ballistic weapons, lasers and mortars/artillery.  Ballistic and lasers have a few variations like cannon, chaingun, machine gun, shotgun etc., and artillery has varying sizes/ranges.

Individual weapons have different stats for things like shield damage, hull damage, fire rate, reload speed, structure damage, penetration, magazine size and total ammo pool.  Penetration is pretty neat, some of the big cannons can fire right through multiple structures.  Nothing like rear-shotting an enemy tank through a city block.

You also get to pick one of four or five special abilites, like smoke screen, cloaking, emp charge.  They have a cooldown, but unlimited use.



I Haven't really played campaign at all, below mission info is about freelance/sandbox mode.

You start by picking an operation from the list.  Any op will always have the same maps and the same number of them.  So "Operation Whatever" will always take place on the drainage map, the slums and the canal for example, but the placement of objectives and enemies will be randomized.

Aside from taking place on different maps, each mission plays out the same.  You unlock the exit by doing at least one of the main objectives - kill a % of all enemies, kill all the commanders, or blow up all of the big artillery structures.  There are also a few side missions that are the same each time.  The more you do, the more money you earn for unlocking stuff.

At higher difficulties with the smaller, more vulnerable units you really need to think ahead and take full advantage of your environment and equipment to survive.

On the surface Brigador is a 2D isometric tank shooter.  Underneath there is a lot of customisation and a wide array of tactics you'll use to avoid an untimely demise.

The campaign mode has loads of missions, most with a choice of four loadouts.  These allow you to try to have a go at each scenario in very different ways.  Freelance mode allows you to set up your own vehilce and choose a set of missions.  There are three vehilce classes (tank, walker, agrav) which all handle in different ways and have significant pros and cons.  In each class there is a spectrum of sizes and the three factions each have their own strengths and weaknesses.

The difficulty in Freelance mode is entirely up to you, there are no easy/medium/hard settings.  Each pilot has a difficulty rating and many get harder as you progress through missions.  Certain vehicles and classes lend themselves to particular weaponry and each weapon has pros and cons.  Some maps are wide and open with lots of room to move but nowhere to hide, others are perfect for sneaking and setting up bottle-neck ambushes but with no room to turn and run.

Its easy to learn in a big heavy tank, able to take a beating and dish out huge damage but you cant run or hide.  In some more difficult missions run and hide is the only thing which can keep you alive.  Projectiles take your vehilces momentum, making fast agravs exceptionally good artillery platorms.

The central theme of Brigador experimentation.  It's easy to find a loadout you like and use it to learn the basics, then start swapping parts and branch out.  Soon you'll find something completely different which works just as well but in a totally different way.

Pros:

It's nice that you can select from 4 premade loadouts; doesn't break the balance of the missions while giving you choices to suit your playstyle and also introducing a new player to the concept of building a loadout. Build a loadout freely by picking a vehicle along with two weapons and a special ability and a pilot to go along with it. Then pick how many levels you want to run. The game determines how the difficulty scales based on which pilot you choose, as well as the payout, with the vehicle you choosing also providing bonus cash if you make it out. Overall:

Brigador is a game with a strong sense of identity. That identity is neon-soaked, synth-scored, vehicular mayhem. There's a ton of unlockables along with a good amount of lore if you care to read it, much of tinged with a dark sense of humor. But the real meat of the game is the all-single-player rampages you get sent on with your tank/mech/hovercraft across the cyberpunk planet of Solo Nobre.

Although there are some light stealth elements and discretion is important at times, overall this is a game that wants you to fully enjoy making damn near everything in sight asplode with the incredible firepower at your disposal. Even just fighting off enemies will often result in extensive collateral damage to the environment. Which is fine, because this game basically tracks "collateral damage" as "bonus points".

Beyond that, the "Freelance" mode offers quite a lot of customization, allowing you to combine whatever weapons with your chassis of choice before setting off for a string of missions. If you want a tiny, tracked motorcycle or battlesuit equipped with grenade launchers? No problem. A massive superheavy tank or hovercraft with a cloaking device? Done! It's all in there, waiting to be unlocked.

One last note: while some objections could still be made about the HUD, I think, (the icons are often rather small and hard to make out) the controls offer a satisfying amount of customization. If you're worried that you'll be stuck with a scheme you hate...don't sweat it too much. As long as twin-stick shooters in general are fun for you, you can likely find a setup that works for you in the options screen here.

If you're looking for something quiet, introspective, or with multiplayer then this isn't the game you want. But if your main objection to Mechwarrior and World of Tanks is that they don't let you demolish enough stuff with your war machines? This is one contract you'll want to accept, Brigador.

36470577.review:
SOLO NOBRE MUST FALL. WELCOME, BRIGADOR. Back in the days we had these shooters Jungle Strike and Desert Strike with (nearly) completely destructible terrain. Then came Syndicate and Syndicate 2, both upping the ante with even more full blown orgy of destruction and endorsing the player to do massive collateral damage on one's wake. Then, on the whole different perspective we had wonderful Mech games in the forms of Mech Warrior series (well, about half of 'em were wonderful, at least) and Mech Commander. From this background comes Brigador, cherry-picks the best parts from its role models and brings us the terrible, beautiful wanton of destruction.

Only after few hours under my belt I already love it. It is both a tactical shooter and nearly limitless sandbox of destruction - like playing with a huge Lego set without assembly instructions and a ton of explosives. Brigador's slightly pixelish, neon light drenched and shadow blotted landscapes get constantly pulverized  under heavy mortar strikes, rip-roaring chainguns, rampaging tanks, stomping mechs, even hover-like flying platforms - and they all are designed in a delightfully wonky way that is completely implausible and yet very delightful, like something out of any 2000AD comic strip pages. 

The game has a quite lengthy campaign dealing with procedurally 'liberating' the colony planet as a group of mercenaries doing it all for money (handsomely paid by a shady megacorporation). You use the cash to buy more drivers, vehicles, weapons, missions and (also very delightful) intel and lore for the mission mode, which I think is the real beef of the game. (Although I have enjoyed the campaign so far, too.) 

You set up your death machine by selecting a hull from towering huge mechs or 'tanks' (more like an apartment block with guns on treads) or flying behemoths to relatively tiny ACPA suits, IFVs or flying platforms, and bolting on them your favored methods of destruction, and off you go. This gives lots of variety into how you plan to pull your job through - level everything with massive firepower, screw dodging and try to just soak the incoming damage with you shields and armour, or be the nimble little bastard that nobody can hit into and surgically strike your targets and dance away from the blasts before the enemy gets their cumbersome big hiney on the spot. Your imagination is the limit. 

Brigador hits my nerve perfectly with its payload of insane scale destruction, frantic shooty-action, tactical aspects and lovely old-skool visuals, not to mention the groovy retro-drenched Synthwave soundtrack pounding on the background. Cherry on the top, the lore is fun to read and gives names and faces on the odd looking things you're either driving yourself or blasting away with glee. Easy to get a grip on, simple enough to learn and time consuming to master with every aspect, Brigador reminds me of good old times - and that we have way too few good Mech games around. Luckily we have this one.

I did not expect a game primarily about piloting mechs and blowing things up to have an incredibly rich, dark aesthetic. While not cyberpunk, it grips tightly to the same tone of a cold, cynical dystopia lit frequently by neon. The gritty style of the game's graphics is used to grand effect with cool-looking weapon effects and explosions. While it carries a certain oldschool feel, being set on an isometric plane, Brigador does not look or feel dated, partially due to its clever use of shaders.

The music, composed by Makeup and Vanity Set (MAVS), could singlehandedly give any best-of playlist put together by New Retrowave a run for its money. This reason alone should justify a purchase if you enjoy music like Perturbator, Carpenter Brut, Mega Drive, or Power Glove.

This game is good. It is quite possibly the peak of indie gaming. I cannot recommend it enough. Buy it.

36379523.review:
Brigador is a game that I wish I had supported earlier in its development and even after dumping 50+ hours into it return every so often for a good hour or so of unbridled destructions and frantic top down mech/tank shooter action. In a nutshell the game takes place in a late 1980’s early 90s esc cyber punk dystopian future where humanity has spread colonies amongst the stars. The game takes place in the city of Solo Nobre, a former corporate mega city turned Cuban esc regime by the efforts of Great Leader and his army the NEP. You as the player take the role of a “Brigador” essentially a mercenary hired by the corporations to accomplish various goals and wreaking as much havoc as possible within Solo Nobre during the chaos brought by great leader’s assassination in exchange for cold hard cash.

	In terms of gameplay brigador plays very much like the old SNES BattleTech top down mech shooter, albeit with a greater degree of polish. The player takes control of one of the various war machines in the game to accomplish their assigned goals and has a wide assortment of weaponry to do so. By completing missions and successfully extracting you earn cash which can be used to unlock various items in the game such as new pilots, vehicles, weapons, and lore documents. Brigador’s gameplay is divided into two major parts the first being the campaign/story mode, in this mode the player must accomplish a series of missions using premade vehicle loadouts. Campaign missions can have a wide assortment of objectives but most boil down to eliminate the target then get out of the district. The second mode is free lance where players can select a pilot (difficulty level and payout multipliers), vehicle and its weapons, as well as what operation (series of levels) they wish to play. Every level will pit you against one of three factions, the NEP, the Corvids, and the Spacers. Each faction has their own vehicle sets (many of which you the player can actually use your self) and have different strengths and weaknesses though these are hardly noticeable when you start deploying with weapons that destroy entire city blocks in a single shot.

	In terms of sound design and eye candy brigador achieves what its going for. The sprawling neon lit city scapes are fully realized in an isometric style reminiscent of command and conquer tiberian sun and dripping with just as much atmosphere. The game’s soundtrack by Makeup and vanity set is simply fantastic and matches the visuals to the letter; I must point out however that the sound design for individual weapons and vehicles tends to rely on reusing sound assets though this is hardly noticeable in the grand scheme of things.

Brigador’s story and world building is perhaps the aspect I love the most about this game, every piece of equipment, vehicle, and pilot has back story detailed in various logs that take on different perspectives some of which going so far as to bring a bit of humor to what would otherwise be a bland lore document. The writing behind some of these logs is pretty clever and though not award winning materiel it certainly does add a bit of depth to what is otherwise just a top down shooter. 

I do thoroughly enjoy this game and would highly recommend it, but I can’t help to see a few problems with it. The most glaring issue I see with the game is how repetitive it can get after a while, once you've completed every campaign mission you turn to freelance, but then it doesn't take long before you're running through the same city districts over and over again; the only real diversity coming from the vehicle and weapon set up your using as well as the possibility that you might be fighting a different faction this time around. A lack of any kind of multiplayer also kinda limits the game’s replayability and effectively makes this a game I play when I have no one else to play with. One last gripe I have is that though all three opposing factions are well fleshed out in terms of design, back story, and visible arsenals they tend to function all the same and lack any kind of behavioral differences.

If I could make suggestions for updates, or changes to be made in any prospective sequel it would be the following.

The inclusion of some kind of coop option for Freelance mode, or any kind of multiplayer really as this gives me incentive to actually recommend the game to friends and increases replayability. 

Diversifying AI behavior between the various factions, everyone in sight rushing at you makes sense for the rag tag corvids or glory seeking spacers, but not so much for the supposedly disciplined NEP.

Perhaps more districts or variations of the various districts so players are not stomping down the same streets over and over in free lance.

The inclusion of further customisation options for the player vehicle, perhaps color tweaks of some kind or vehicles with more than just two weapons slots.

35748520.review:
Brigador: Up-Armored Edition

Resumo:

Um título de muitas qualidades. Excelente arte, apresentação viva, cheia de cores e cercada de qualificada sonorização. Interessante mecânica de combate, talvez lenta demais para o gosto de alguns, mas bem implementada. Alguns problemas parecem ter restringido um tanto o público. Brigador é um jogo que não se compromete com narrativa, mas com a satisfação de um combate difícil em uma apresentação retrô. Mas não é um jogo para público diversificado e possui alguns problemas, além de um preço um tanto acima do que deveria ser.

Recomendo com desconto a partir de 50%.

-----------

Brigador é um ótimo jogo em diversos aspectos. Música é excelente, sonorização é muito boa. As cores vivas e o detalhamento do cenário em perspectiva isométrica dão ao jogo um visual retrô e tornam a ação bastante peculiar.

Há um modo história com uma grande quantidade de missões para as quais você tem entre 1 e 3 veículos disponíveis para fechar o cenário. Cada cenário demanda, basicamente, que o jogador destrua uma determinada quantidade de alvos específicos e depois saia do cenário.

Há uma boa variedade de Mechs, veículos e também pilotos (que possuem seus próprios atributos), ao lado de uma variedade de armas. Tudo pode ser destravado com pontos obtidos em modos arcade e campanha (uma espécie de tutorial). Cada veículo e arma funcionam bastante diferente uns dos outros, dando incrível relevância mecânica às escolhas do jogador.

O jogo possui uma tradução razoavelmente bem revisada para Português Brasileiro, mas não há muito para ser lido na parte da narrativa. Não que não haja texto, mas o texto é (também em versão original) desinteressante e pouco brilhante em relação ao visual.

Praticamente TUDO no cenário é destrutível, há boa quantidade de tipos diferentes de inimigos, mas nada que funcione como um BOSS ou chefão. Dificuldade está relacionada aos tipos de táticas que o jogador deve adotar para cada tipo de inimigo e de acordo com a quantidade e inimigos acumulados ao redor.

Você vai lembrar de todo e qualquer jogo do passado envolvendo mechs, veículos armados e filmes de ação dos anos 90. E isso é bastante para me deixar interessado, mas não é o suficiente para fazer uma recomendação a preço total.

Brigador não é bem um jogo para diversos públicos. Não é rápido nem simples o suficiente para quem gosta de twin stick shooters. O visual é cheio demais de detalhes que prejudicam a percepção visual necessária para um jogo de ação tática (especialmente quando você acumula inimigos e precisa ajustar distância de disparo). 

Você pode imaginar que sistema ideal para controle é um gamepad, mas o jogo parece ter sido feito principalmente com teclado e mouse em mente. O controle de distância da mira com uso dos sticks é ineficiente. É possível jogar com gamepad, mas melhor desempenho é obtido com teclado e mouse.

Uma excelente apresentação, mas com uma execução muito restritiva. O jogo pode não prender você depois da terceira hora. Você sentirá vontade de voltar a ele de vez em quando, mas não apenas a mecânica cansativa, como também o visual cheio parecem não ser apropriados para longas sessões.

Um bonito e interessante jogo. Mas que eu não posso recomendar a preço total... recomendo com desconto de 50% ou mais.

Let me start off by saying I'm not a fan of retro games. I don't like pixel graphics, or 'trendy' indy crap. At the risk of being burned at the stake for heresy, I'm also not a fan of videogame music. What I do like are RPG's and mecha.

The screenshots for the game had me concerned that the game would be pixelated and look like old crap, fortunately actual gameplay looked a lot better than the screenshots suggest. The level of detail is excellent, and it's full 3D. They managed to give the game a retro look without deliberately forgoing modern advancements in technology. 

The gameplay plays out in full 3d in spite of the flat terrain and isometric view. There is a degree of skill in controlling the elevation of flat trajectory shots. The balance of the game is also excellent. There is a lot to unlock, but nothing feels inaccessible or out of reach. See a mech you like? You can probably buy it after 2-4 missions. Buying a new mech, tank, or hovercar isn't so much about buying power as it is about buying a new playstyle, same with the weapons. If you want to be big and stompy with lots of armor and big guns, go right ahead. If you want to be fast and agile with mortars and strategic weapons using indirect tactics, go for it. It's not a matter of one being better, it's about which one you feel like doing at that moment. This means there is minimal grind to get the things you want, but a hefty time investment to unlock everything, so lots of content without the boredom. The destructible terrain is great, it gives the feeling of mass destruction and mayhem. You feel powerful, but not indestructible.

As for complaints, it's easy to get turned around with tanks and mechs so you're walking backwards exposing your rear armor, and difficult and time consuming to set it straight again. Important information about weapons isn't displayed in the store before buying. Will they fire directly or are they mortars? Do they fire single shot, burst , or full auto? You have to buy to find out. Fortunately buying them isn't too expensive depending on the class, and they follow a repeating pattern in their order, at least for type. The menu, while functional, is clunky, this was a stylistic choice to maintain the retro 90's arcade aesthetic, so it's more a matter of opinion. Also, purely a matter of preference, it's light on the RPG elements. It's not advertised as an RPG, it just would have been more enjoyable to me personally if it were. More in depth vehicle customization would have also been nice, but wouldn't really work with their current direction of quick action. This is, again, a matter of preference, some people, like myself, enjoy pouring over builds and getting involved with management level meta, other people just want to get into the action and play, this game caters to the latter.

To summarize, in many ways this game isn't what I normally prefer, but it is an excellent well-crafted game. A lot of love went into getting things right, and extra effort into the detail.

It took me a long time to think about what I'd say about Brigador, as I usually list a negative first and I'm very judgemental when it comes to games. Brigador only had very mild negatives, along with some very strong positives that makes it difficult for me to say anything bad about it

From an excellent soundtrack to the incredible gameplay, to the lore and graphics design, everything about Brigador appears to have been well made and shows great attention to detail. A gentle learning curve and a campaign that will teach you and then present you with ever increasing challenges followed with free play contracts that will let you go at the speed and difficulty you prefer means that you will always be able to customize your experience to tailor it to what you like and what you can handle. 
The maps are designed well and pretty to look at, with everything inside except for the map boundaries being fully destructible. You are even encouraged to do so, and destroying things gives you a bonus. 

A large selection of vehicles, weaponry and enemies ensures that there is a lot for you to choose from, with every piece of gear you pick having its use and using your gear well is usually the key to success. But with all that gear, you can pick and choose how you want to play. Stealth, guns blazing, or a mix is all possible with none of the weapons seeming overpowered or underpowered. And everything you see ingame is a thing you can take and use.

The only negative I've found was the control scheme, which doesn't always work well with every vehicle. But it is barely a negative as you can change your control scheme as needed. Out of all the things in game, everything works together amazingly well and handles great, both in the missions and with the overarching theme.

Brigador is one of those rare games where you do not regret any moment of your time playing it. Everything can be made to be the way you enjoy it the best while at the same time offering you challenges exactly the way you want them. It seems to do everything right and has no real negatives to it that I could find. Brigador tells you to enjoy yourself, and it gives you all the tools you need to do so.

34364592.review:
When I caught wind of Brigador being similar to one of my favorite classic games, Urban Strike (part of a great series of Strike games), I was immediately determined to pick it up.  Those games and their gameplay were some of my favorite on my Sega Genesis as a kid.  While Brigador isn’t exactly like those games, it gave me just enough of a nostalgia trip to really get in to it and enjoy it's hearty gameplay.

[h1]Who is your Brigador and what does he do?[/h1]

Brigador: Up-Armored Edition is an updated version of the original game released in June of 2016 after eight months in Early Access.  The re-released update dropped in June of 2017 and added some missions to the campaign, updated the graphics, and did some rebalancing.  I had the pleasure of playing both since I got the game just before this update.  I can say that it is more appealing now than it was before, though even with the balance changes there can be some rough difficulty spikes that you will come across.  The core of the gameplay in the campaign is relatively simple.  You’ll grab one of the next missions in the group you’ve unlocked (usually three or four at a time), perhaps read the gist of what you’ll be doing and why, select one of the four pre-established vehicles, and head in to blow up nearly everything in sight.  The vehicles come in a large variety.  There are tanks and wheeled vehicles, hovertanks, and bipedal mechs, all of which range in size from tiny you lose them on screen to fairly larger and slow to maneuver.  These are each outfitted with a unique loadout of weapons and abilities that can be better or worse suited for the type of missions you encounter.  However, the campaign is designed to have you replay missions as many times as you want and receive marks for beating it in each provided vehicle.  Going through it the first time I gravitated toward the larger and more heavily armed and armored vehicles in most situations because that’s the playstyle I like, however I could see how the faster and more stealthy vehicles could work very well too if you practiced with them.

Once in the mission, you’ll have a list of your objectives in the top corner and little else guiding you through except some icons along the edges of you screen indicating the direction of the objectives.  You can move through at your own pace on your own path, or just carve it out of the destructible level.  Vehicles and buildings will crumble and explode at the whim of your mouse clicks.  Enemies vary just as much as your choice in vehicles from small and super-fast to much larger than anything you can pilot and equally slow.  Their firepower can be just as diverse.  Dispatching them may take a sweep of your machine gun or have you running around dodging their shots as you pick them apart.  Objectives are simple at best, usually requiring you to either blow up certain buildings or special vehicles, or just wiping out 70% of the enemies on the map (and sometimes both).  However, the unique design of each map makes it much less repetitive than such a limited set of objectives would indicate.  Plus, the real challenge comes to the surface when you have to manage both the health of your vehicle along with its  ammo that runs out several times a mission, requiring you to salvage ammo pickups from not-completely-destroyed enemies or finding the handful of ammo depots with limited supply.  The raw carnage and combination of action and tactical efforts from the player really define the beginning and end of what makes Brigador so fun.

[h1]What else is going on?[/h1]

Well, there’s a metric ton of story lore in the game.  There’s a tiny bit presented in the campaign, but the majority is unlocked via the money that you earn for each mission.  This money has no effect on the campaign itself as far as I can tell, but you earn a great deal going through the missions.  You can spend it on unlocking tons of in-game content including vehicle and enemy descriptions, story elements of all sorts including information about the factions involved, freelance mission items that include vehicles, vehicle pilots with varying mission modifiers, and equipment for those vehicles.  This leaves a pretty robust amount of gameplay even after you finish the campaign that, if you wanted to complete fully with all vehicles would take many hours beyond the four-plus I used to run through it once each.  The lore and descriptions you can unlock weave a giant web of story content that is entirely optional to the player, but it seems to be something the developers put a lot of effort in to.  There’s even an audio book included with the Deluxe edition, which I think I received just for having the game before it re-released.  Also included in that Deluxe edition is a great soundtrack of perfectly crafted synthwave music that meshes with the explosive gameplay surprisingly well.  It’s very prominent, so if it’s not a type of music you’re in to, you’re going to have to turn it off entirely.  However, for me it was great and I left its pumping beats and 80s aesthetic going strong the whole way through.

[h1]So did anything suck?[/h1]

There were a few smaller issues and some larger ones that really had me drinking the rageahol.  The health system in Brigador has you maintaining both your standard health and a shield that can be recharged by enemy drops.  However, your normal health can’t be fixed by anything in a mission.  This isn’t a problem in most missions that are relatively short an simple, but some missions are a bit longer and any encounter with a lot of enemies can wear your non-reparable health down, making a small mistake force you to restart.  On top of that, shield drops disappear after a period.  This means that if you’re working with long range weapons or slow moving vehicles, a large firefight may have you missing out on the lifeblood you need to keep going.  Another small issue is that you have to learn about the environments in a bit of a trial by fire.  Some buildings will explode killing you instantly if you run into them or destroy them from too close.  It can be difficult to distinguish these and result in an unexpected and frustrating death.  They could easily be marked in an more obvious way, but they often blend in too well.  The most annoying thing I encountered was the difficulty spikes.  Some missions would be many times harder than missions before or after.  I played through one probably 15 or 20 times as it had you starting with no ammo and dodging insta-kill suicide enemies to get to the ammo depots.  In addition, the final optional campaign mission is significantly longer than previous ones and trying to maintain health during it is nearly impossible with what vehicles are supplied.  If this is the rebalanced version, I’d hate to have seen what some of these later missions were like before that.

[h1]Recommendation?[/h1]

This really is a good game and I would suggest getting it for $10 or less as it has been (and currently is on GOG) under that price.  While it may lack some of the things that I really enjoyed about those old Strike games, it does have some solid mechanics that the player can improve and master throughout the tons of replayability provided.  Fans of the whole ‘you against the world’ concept in games, where you’re mowing down enemies like a badass, will definitely find this appealing.

If you'd like to see more of my reviews, check out my curator page here: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/EndyoGaming#curation

If the price of the game is under 15$, I'd personally say it's worth it.
This is an isometric, tiled game which only has the destruction part of Blast Corps(n64).
(You are a mech in the middle of a city, killing and crushing people and destroying their homes and power plants)
So it has an old style to it, which seems to be appreciated by most.

The campaign has a nice, not annoying tutorial, which not only teaches you the dirty way but you get to keep all your earnings and spend it in freelance mode. I believe if you play the entire campaign, you can get enough dough to buy some of the best available. 

In freelance, you can buy a pilot, a vehicle, weapons and missions (and lore; intel but w/e)
Here's one of the brilliant part of the game.. The biggest, baddest vehicles are worth the least and the smallest, weakest vehicles are worth the most. Why? Because each vehicle has a payout modifier, wanna make it hard on yourself but earn three times more than anyone else? Use the tiniest vehicle. Wanna wreck havoc or get through a long and hard series of missions? Use a big bad vehicle and tear the place apart.

Pilots also get to have such modifiers but I first need to explain missions (Operations as they are called in-game).
Operations are basically a series of missions, smallest being a series of 2 but can get up to a whopping 39!
You have to be careful though, as your vehicle does not repair itself nor rearm itself between missions.
During each missions, you have a set of main objectives and a set of optional objectives (They're all about killing and destruction). You can end the current mission after completing at least one main objective, or you can stay and complete the level to gain more money. As you finish the entire operation, the money you've earned will be multiplied by some factors, such as the type of vehicle and pilot you've used.

33749773.review:
As a piece of art, as an exhibition of neon-techno-giant-mech-destroying-buildings aesthetic, Brigador is pretty fabulous. There's no denying the sound, art, writing come together as a cohesive whole. But as a piece of design, as a game meant to be played, it leaves a lot to be desired.

I played long enough to beat the campaign and to give the more open-ended Freelance mode a couple whirls, and I kept waiting for the game to hook me. I tried playing with the biggest mechs with the best weapons and destroying everything in sight. I tried playing with the smaller vehicles, ones that required more strategy and were more difficult. I tried completing every side objective on a map. I tried speed-running through them instead. Didn't matter. The game never felt compelling. It never felt more than a superficial, mildly entertaining romp through rectangular districts that mostly look the same.

There's a lot of design approaches a game can take to hook the player and while Brigador dabbles in some of them, none of them were implemented well enough to draw me in:

-A game can hook by providing interesting characters with character arcs (like the Telltale Games). There are no characters in Brigador and certainly no character arcs.

-A game can hook by providing an interesting plot / environment with mysteries to uncover (like Bioshock). The plot here is paper-thin. You get summaries before each mission, but they're only providing an explanation of the objectives. Basically you're a mercenary who blows stuff up because some text told you to. There's no sense of progress, no meaningful advancement of story.

-A game can hook by providing a meaningful challenge (like Dark Souls). Difficulty in Brigador is problematic, as it primarily comes from willfully choosing poor tools for the job. For example, in a given campaign map, you can choose a massive mech with double lasers that can take a lot of punishment or you can choose a tiny sniper mech that is easily destroyed. Some people enjoy this - and I think these people may appreciate the options Brigador provides. I do not. I love difficulty - but I love difficulty that the game provides, not that I must generate by willfully making poor choices or placing arbitrary restrictions on myself.

-A game can hook by providing stat / gear / unlock progression (like Diablo 3). Brigador's open-ended Freelance method provides an extensive list of things to unlock, including new weapons, mechs, & pilots. While the pilots represent difficulty options and don't otherwise affect gameplay, the weapons all felt unique and interesting, an excellent feat given how many there are. Unfortunately, the campaign has NO progression. For each map, you're provided a couple pre-made loadouts and that's that.

-A game can hook by providing exploratory elements, such as new environments, hidden collectibles, bigger and scarier opponents, etc. There is some variety in the level design - rural vs. junk city vs. regular city - but none of it ever really *pops.* Same with unit design. You do eventually encounter some larger mechs but it's genuinely kind of hard to tell the difference because the game is so dark and zoomed out. It desperately needed paint jobs, decals, etc on the mechs, to distinguish them from each other. Even the three factions are remarkably similar. Furthermore, there are no hidden collectibles, no secret bosses, none of that. In fact, there are no bosses at all, which seems a wasted opportunity.

Ultimately, the game isn't compelling. This is unfortunate as it clearly has some excellent elements. I personally would love to play a Brigador 2 that bothered to create a compelling story with interesting characters; with levels that had unique & clear design (rather than the randomly generated feel they all have now); with an intelligent progression from small mechs and weak weapons to large mechs and powerful weapons. Maybe even some multiplayer elements, like horde defense co-op, CTF, etc. That game would be frikkin awesome. Unfortunately, Brigador is not that game.

== GAMEPLAY (The mechanical part of the game) ==
You walk around in your mech, tank, or antigrav vehicle and destroy the marked objectives in the map, and you have two weapons and an active ability. In Campign mode, these are chosen for you, but you can choose your own loadout in Freelance mode. Different weapons behave differently against buildings, enemy shields and hull, and different vehicles behave differently to enemy fire and terrain types. This gives the player some things to consider both when choosing their loadout or making tactical decissions in battle. The game is more tactical than anything, since choosing in what order you deal with enemies, how you position yourself, and when you use your active ability is more important to survival than how you use your weapons. Weapons, however, do behave differently mechanically, some weapons have travel speed and others are more of "hitscan" weapons, most shoot in a straight line down to the ground, but others fire like a shotgun spread, or even high-arch projectiles.
6/10 - Good

== AESTHETICS (The audiovisual presentation of the game) ==
If you've heard about this game before, you must have heard about the soundtrack. Have the studio chosen some usual orchestral or rock music, the game could've felt cheap and uninteresting. The original synthwave soundtrack by one of the best artists in the genere, Makeup and Vanity Set (and some others since the Up-Armored update) ultimately gives the game a unique ambient and soul. The graphics are a love letter to 90s to early 2000s isometric sci-fi games. The player and enemy vehicles are 2D sprites with 64 different angles pre-rendered from 3D models with normal maps cooked in for interaction with the game's lighting effects, which give the finishing touch to the cyberpunk setting of the game. The game easily runs at 60FPS, but the pre-made animations for mechs and enemies have a very low ammount of frames. This deliberate choice, along with the semi-uncanny valley illustrations for pilot portraits, give off a very classic and somewhat unsettling feeling to the game, similar to some of Scott Cawthon's (creator of FNAF) earlier works (see: The Desolate Hope).
10/10 - Masterpiece

== CHALLENGE (The thought put into the challenges the game gives to the player) ==
The game gives a lot of opportunity for the player to tweak the difficulty of the game. First, the game speed setting: the player is allowed to change the speed of both themselves and the enemies (from 50% to 100% speed, set to 80% by default). Then there's the pilots: as the player progresses, they can unlock new pilots, and each of them is essentially a different combination of payout and difficulty modifiers, form one that makes it so that no enemies will ever spawn to get only a tenth of the pay, to pilots locked into the highest difficulties at all times in exchange for some big buck, even ones that will start at a low difficulty and gradually increase for each sector cleared, a sector being one of the different levels in each mission. Loadout choice also goes into play: some weapons have a low ammo capacity but deal very high damage (like lasers and explosives), others have a high ammo capacity and high fire rate in exchange for low damage per bullet (like gatling guns and turret guns), which can make ammo management (a very important part of the game) easier. Finally there's vehicle choice: bigger vehicles are louder, but more resilient, while smaller ones are more silent, but fragile. Each vehicle has a different combination of factors to consider: movement speed, movement acceleration, aiming speed, turning speed, hull, shields, temporary shields (an extra shield that fades out over time), etc. Some vehicles are even at a direct disadvantage to others or pose a higher risk to the player, but compensate it by giving an extra payout when the mission is done. It's a big mish-mash of ways to tweak the game to your liking.

Brigador is great. I came to the game with the expectation of giant stompy robots, but it ended up being a general vehicular mayhem simulator of the highest degree. A large campaign acts as a delivery mechanism for training and challenge missions, but the Freelance mode offers you large, open-ended "runs" to test your mettle with whatever configurations you can cook up, and is arguably the more compelling game mode once you have the basics down.

It's a skill-based game - weapons have distinct firing arcs based on their properties and where they're mounted on your vehicle as well as different colour-coded ammo types, and vehicle facing is important to mitigate how much damage you take. The controls are nonetheless simple enough to get the hang of with a bit of training, but learning to operate vehicles with finesse will take time and practice (which is exactly what I'm looking for in this sort of game).

Special note of the fact that once you're on a map, the game lets go of your hand and you're on your own. Brigador presents your objectives, and its up to you *how* you complete them, or whether you can complete them at all. Several side-objectives let you influence the map in interesting ways too (as well as earning more filthy lucre). Coming up with priorities for what objectives you can actually afford to complete (or end up HAVING to complete due to your actions) lends a nice layer of strategy to what would otherwise be frivolous stompenshoot. The fact that you can destroy literally anything on the map to carve your own path through is not only fun, but useful given the open-ended nature of the maps.

Two minor complaints would be that it's not always terribly clear when you're taking damage or where from, and your firing arcs don't indicate when they're obstructed by terrain, meaning that you may inadvertently waste a lot of ammo demolishing walls instead of your foes. It's also not always clear which Freelance runs you've previously completed. These are minor issues, though, and don't overwhelmingly detract from the game.

If any of this sounds appealing, buy this game.

32836986.review:
[h1]La trifulca de los días futuros[/h1]

Adquirí Brigador en un Humble Bundle mensual. Unos días después de añadirlo a mi librería, empecé a notar más titulares que hablaban del juego, de sus desarrolladores y el cambio de su suerte. Según la historia, Brigador es un proyecto que se negó a la tentación del kickstarter y después de varios años de desarrollo, logró la mayoría de sus propósitos; creo que el equipo de Stellar Jockeys hizo bien y que fueron sensatos, cautelosos, porque si no luego pasan cosas extrañas como con Chroma Squad.

Sin embargo, no lo niego, la apuesta fue demasiado arriesgada. Supongo que todavía lo es. Pocos juegos tienen desarrollos tan aventurados y felices como este.

Brigador es un juego de sprites isométrico donde rentas a tu piloto a una organización anarquista y manejas mechas, vehículos y tanques para destruir las ciudades de un gobierno autoritario. Hay una historia ahí, pero se construye a base de pocas certezas, bastantes rumores, sin dejar descansar al humor negro y la ironía, lo cual, personalmente, me parece un deleite. La mayoría de los pilotos son mercenarios y tiene un trasfondo entre trágico y cínico.

Estos pequeños fragmentos de historia van acorde con el entorno cyberpunk del juego y engalanan, dan una profundidad sabrosísima, a las ilustraciones de los pilotos (quienes asombran y hacen reír, o sonreír, porque mis preferidos son los que parecen luchadores de bar, aquellos que beben una chelita de más y malacopean para pronto entrarle a los madrazos). Al juego lo acompaña música de sintetizadores muy ochentera; ¿estamos cansados de este renacimiento de los ochenta el cual parece no tiene llenadera? Para nada, Brigador lo hace muy bien.

En cuanto al juego, puedes usar mouse y teclado o gamepad. Sospecho que el mouse y teclado son mejores, o más prácticos, para Brigador pero eventualmente logré configurar mi dual shock 4 para jugarlo cómodamente (importante: tienes que moverle a la configuración hasta que quede, si no, te frustrarás mucho).

Hay tres tipos de vehículos y cada uno tiene diversas opciones a configurar (armas y especiales): los mechas, automóviles y tanques, dependiendo de su tamaño y su movilidad, son más robustos o más ágiles, o quizás son tan débiles que son especiales para situaciones de sigilo y demandan juegos mejor planeados y estratégicos. Los desarrolladores no escatimaron recursos para probar diferentes tipos de vehículos y complacer a jugadores de distintos estilos de juego. Hay un modo campaña el cuál es de pilotos fijos y tiene entre tres o cuatro dificultades (o modos de juego, dependiendo), o bien, puedes jugar al freelancer y armar una serie de mapas continuos para probar una configuración personal y ver hasta dónde puedes llegar antes de morir o de llevarte el botín gordo.

El modo Freelancer es donde brilla el juego y donde pasarás más tiempo. En ambos modos, tanto la campaña como en el freelancing, los pilotos ganan y acumulan dinero que utilizarás para comprar más opciones: mapas, vehículos, pilotos, fragmentos de la historia o estrategias (un bestiario con los vehículos y las cosas que destruyes). Cada cosa, según la configuras, modifica este modo de juego. Los mapas, por ejemplo, entre más dinero inviertes en ellos, abren más zonas y secuencias a visitar. Los pilotos y los vehículos modifican la dificultad del mapa por cada zona vencida además de alterar el multiplicador de dinero. Por supuesto, puedes configurar este modo para escoger todos los atributos del azar y que esto sea una sorpresa o bien, puedes buscar y perfeccionar a tu Brigador con una configuración que te permita pasar las zonas más altas. Hay tantas combinaciones posibles que hay Brigador para rato.

Ojo: algunos vehículos, claro, están diseñados para ser verdaderas máquinas de la muerte, no sólo para los habitantes de Solo Nobre (el planeta que estás liberando) pero también para los propios pilotos. Entre más difícil de manejar sean los vehículos, más altos son los multiplicadores de dinero.

El diseño del juego me recuerda, brevemente, a un juego isométrico que jugué alguna vez: Syndicate. O quizás el primerísimo de los príncipes de Persia. Sí, bueno, pero actualizado a una calidad de 1080p. Las animaciones son fluidas, demasiado bien cuidadas, se nota un trabajo obsesivo, artístico. Reconocerás un placer extraño en apreciar los movimientos de los pequeños hombrecillo de gabardina amarilla a los que aplastas. Es palpable el esfuerzo por dar profundidad y diseño a los vehículos y sus texturas. Los escenarios y edificios recuerdan a los settings de otras obras cyberpunk o distópicas como Blade Runner, Akira o Max Headroom. Pero no sólo hay parques industriales, sucios, pero también hay suburbios y zonas de cultivo que contrastan perfectamente con lo anteriormente mencionado. De los retratos de los pilotos ya hablé antes, pero el realismo con el que están diseñados además de sus historias breves logran conectar con el jugador de la mejor manera: permiten que uno  complete los puntos e intuya las historias.

Lamentablemente el juego no tiene multijugador. Pero es perfecto en un sólo jugador para destruir ciudades en breves ráfagas casuales (de 20 a 30 minutos) o en largas sesiones de juego.

¿Lo recomiendo? Sí. Brigador es destrucción masiva con un diseño neón y retro. Sus modos de juego mantendrán despiertos a los luchadores y a los apostadores por igual.

32810064.review:
Brigador is one of those games where there's not a whole lot of things you can really say about it, because of how straight forward it is. But that's not a bad thing.

Brigador brings back a style of isometric action games that we've not really seen in some time. If you've ever played the "strike" series (Desert Strike, Nuclear Strike and so on), or the slightly more obscure "Mass Destruction", you know roughly what type of game it is. You're unleashed on the world in a heavily armed vehicle, and your goal is to destroy things. Brigador is not a clone of those mentioned games though, and in most ways, it's a better game. If nothing else, it's a lot faster, and has more going on at all time.  
  
[B]Graphics & Sound[/B] 
The graphics in Brigador is clean, sharp & detailed. While not as technically advanced as many other modern games, Brigador does still look darn good, owing to a strong consistent art style. The screenshots are representative, that is what the game looks like. And while they might look a bit cluttered, it's usually not too hard to figure out what's going on on screen at any given moment. And yes, those are coloured lights that would make a late 90's 3D action game, like Forsaken, green with envy. Unlike those late 90's games, the use of coloured light does not end up feeling tacky though, it works.

Brigador is no slouch in the audio department either. The soundtrack fits well in with the 80's/early 90's style cyberpunk feel that the game has, and helps set the mood. All weapons have suitable sound effects that make them feel like they have some weight behind them, without feeling overbearing and obnoxious. Audio feedback is very important in a game like Brigador, and it nails it. 

[B]Gameplay[/B]
You're playing as an armoured vehicle, be it a tank, mech or some other vehicle outfitted with heavy weapons. And your goal is to cause as much destruction as you possibly can. Each level has its own set of objectives, that usually boil down to "kill X, Destroy Y, then escape", with secondary objectives that are similar in nature. It's all very straight forward, and the game does not really stray from this formula. Depending on if you're playing the campaign, or just randomly generated maps, you either have a set of 3-4 different vehicles to chose from, or you get to design your own from parts that you've unlocked. 
Exactly how you play will depend on your vehicle. Some are light and nippy, and need to always be on the move to avoid incoming projectiles, others are lumbering behemoths that can take a beating. And there's also a good variety in the weapons, with things like mortars, machine guns, heavy cannons, shotguns and so on making up the arsenal. So despite the games rather straight forward gameplay, the variety in playstyles between vehicles still make the game feel like it has a lot of variety. 
The game encourages you to play aggressively in most cases. Collateral damage is not just not punished, but even encouraged, as you'll get greater rewards the more things you end up destroying along the way. And destroying things in Brigador feels far more satisfying than it has any right to do. 

[B]Final Thoughts[/B]
Brigador is a great game. It's easy to pick up and play, and it's just darn fun. It might not be the deepest game on the market, but few games I've played match the sheer amount of fun I've had with Brigador. It's going to be one of those games that will stay on my HDD for a long time, and whenever I just feel like blowing stuff up, I'll start Brigador. So for anyone who's looking for a straight forward action game, I can't recommend Brigador enough.

These are all very positive things. From the get go it has an immediate personality in it's presentation that will suck you in, and the carnal combat within will get you hooked. 

So let's break it down.

PROS:
-----------------------------------------------
- Great visuals, unique presentation
- A loving amount of detail has gone into desiging the weird and wild technological machines at your disposal, from the actual visual designs to the variety of weapons and their functions, stats and even flavortext herein. If you like customizing a mech not unlike armored core or such, you're gonna have fun with this.
- Gleeful amount of destructibility in all maps. The world is your sandbox to topple over and stomp.
- Great soundtrack. I'll admit I'm not as into the overt 80's synth stuff as some people, but if you like that kind of music, this is grade A material for you up with the likes of Hotline Miami. 
-Surprisingly fleshed out world building in the descriptions of pilots, locations, weapons, mechs, etc. It's nothing groundbreaking in it's own right, but it provides quite a bit of grim flavoring to what is, at first glance, a seemingly simple game. 


CONS:
-----------------------------------------
-Loadtimes are juuust long enough and the actual missions juuust short enough to give some noticable speedbumps to what is otherwise a fast and addictive game. 

- The weapon trajectory beams and targeting reticule UI. They manage to do a lot with it that helps feed you immediate information on potential targets. However, the trajectory beams are so bright and colorful they wind up distracting you from the actual targeting reticule, making aiming a slapdash process in the middle of a raging firefight. It's something that I think ought to be tweaked, and a minor inconvience overall- nothing game breaking. 


TL;DR :
-------------------------------------------
Can't reccomend it to everyone, but if you love mechs, mayhem, or just enjoy some of that garish neon 80s dystopia, this is a fun distraction that deserves a bit more recognition.

Everything can be destroyed and nothing is safe from your wrath. There's a big variety of vehicles to choose from, all with different strengths and weaknesses. Some are slick high tech walking mechs, some are tanks made of scrap metal, some are just motorbikes or buses with guns welded to them. All are brutally destructive. 

The soundtrack is fantastic with a lot of pumping synthwave tracks and the sounds of gunfire and explosions are very satisfying. 

If you're into retro 90's games with lots of neon and synth, or if you like isometric action games, you'll enjoy Brigador.

32357547.review:
This game is intensely good. The game encourages you to constantly gage how much challenge you're willing or able to take on and then always raise the stakes a little higher for greater reward. For instances, your choice of operator determines the starting difficulty and how it ramps up, while your vehicle determines the amount of firepower you can level at said challenge: more expensive operators face greater challenges for more rewards, while more expensive vehicles are substantially weaker and less durable but also grant better reward multipliers. This contrasts with other games that make you work to get the most powerful equipment; in this game, you get some of the most powerful things for free by default, and the rest are quite cheap. If you want to drive what is basically the Tuk Tuk from Just Cause 2, however, that'll run you a price so steep that it's 4x more than next most expensive vehicle, but it'll give you a 10x payout multiplier!

The number of completable objectives on each map is much greater than what you need to move on (and they can have good or dangerous consequences if you complete them), and you can often jump to the final payout mission well before completing all of the maps leading up to it. Every single object that breaks or person that dies adds to your paycheck, but you have to manage your ammo stores and your time may be worth more if spent on the objectives.

This creates a subtle ingraining of Brigador morality: Whatever it takes to get paid and get off world is paramount. You will be financially compensated for stomping on innocents, ramming through slums, and collateral damage, but you will probably find that it's not worth your time to go out of your way to do so. Civilians are worth so little to kill that shooting them on purpose may feel like a waste of resources. So, when you DO go out of your way to destroy the lives of the little people, there can be no room for doubt that you act as perversely as the Auditer or greedily beyond all reason.

Speaking of, the lore in this game is so good. Spacers in particular are genuinely unsettling in creative ways: their mechs are clearly backwards and all of their vehicles sport full-yellow paint jobs (the lore says that yellow on Solo Nobre is associated with peaceful surrender and that wearing it while fighting is utmost sacrilege; I wonder if the Spacers are even aware of that) but with bullseyes on the cockpits (which, again, appear to be on the wrong side of the mech). The aforementioned Auditer is merely the operator you can use to tour each map without worrying about hostile forces, but the lore makes an impressive effort turning him into an unusual and almost horrifying character.

If you do try to use a controller, definitely slow the game speed down. The aiming controls are much better suited to a mouse than a joypad, so a lower speed will give you some extra time to adjust the angle of elevation of your shots. For keyboard and mouse, I use Relative Controls for mechs/tanks but Screen Absolute for agravs (I may switch to Top Right Absolute but I have yet to try it).

I'm a bored person, usually. I don't tend to see games in my library and immediately go "Yea, let's play that!"

Brigador has managed to not just be a game I play. Within two hours, it's managed to be a game I'll sometimes click on while paging through my list, and immediately boot up.

Graphically, this feels like looking at a 90s game, but you know how when you don't watch or play or read something for a long time, you come back and it really shows it's age? Brigador feels like a very old game that has somehow managed to dodge that effect. In a world of low-poly 3d and "8-Bit" in name only, this striks a very odd balance that I absolutely adore.

Lore-wise I'm very fond of what they do. Every vehicle, weapon, enemy profile, and article has a small chunk of lore, usually under a paragraph. I feel it fits the game's atmosphere, a mercenary isn't going to know much beyond their objectives unless the actively dig for data.

While I do love this game, it's not perfect, and the gameplay is where I actually have a few complaints. Mechs and tanks control fine, but inexplicably Agravs- armed hovercraft available to pilots- drive incredibly poorly on my machine. There's indication that moving forward in a mech moves you towards the mouse in an agrav, yet they seem to control like tanks no matter what I do. Effectively, this makes them much weaker tanks with the relatively nice ability of flying over low cover and not getting bogged down in debris.

Speaking of debris: in massive fields of it, and those do tend to pop up wherever you go, it's hard to tell what's a flat plane you can walk through, and what's still standing. 

For a game with emphasis on destruction, explosive weapons and elements tend to be a bit lackluster visually. They're still very effective, but the actual blast seems significantly smaller than it should be.

Yet I feel like the best praise I can give here is that even though I have complaints, this is without a doubt my favorite game released this year. I've enjoyed my time with it so far, and the game seems to indicate that I have a very long way to go before I'm scraping the barrel. I hope this is a sign of the rebirth of content-rich singleplayer, because I would love to write more recommendations in the future and be able to say that this was the start of the trend.

I really appreciate that this game manages to make you feel like a badass based on your skill alone, and the devs didn't feel the need to implement skill trees or some sort of character progression system. It's unabashedly arcade-ish in this mentality, but it still manages to have a surprising amount of tactical depth when choosing how to approach groups of enemies or defended positions.

I haven't played the original release of Brigador but I think the complaints about it being hard to control are overstated. I started playing on the new control scheme but settled for tank controls for all vehicles. The absolute control scheme seems more responsive on a keyboard/mouse, especially for the agravs - it allows you to strafe and circle around your opponents with ease. I imagine the new control scheme would be great for a gamepad, though I'm still skeptical about the agravs. Anyway, my point is, the people who write this off because of the control scheme are giant babies. There's nothing wrong with it, and you have plenty of choices in how you choose to control your vehicle.

Music is another highlight for me. It's really well done retro electronica, cca late 70s/early 80s. Obvious comparisons would be John Carpenter movies, Tangerine Dream soundtracks, maybe Blade Runner in parts. 

Overall probably one of the funnest action games I've played in the past while. It manages to recreate that satisfying MechCommander feeling of playing with giant robots, but replaces its clunky combat with sleek, streamlined, and surprisingly kinetic action - moves have heft and explosions feel punchy and dangerous. 

With this re-release pretty much patching up everything people complained about, including adding an extensive tutorial campaign, even more vehicles, weapons, etc. as well as planning additional content to be released in the near future, this is probably the best time to get this game. I hope it achieves some sort of cult status at some point, because it really deserves it. This game is to the Desert/Jungle Strike series what Shovel Knight was for NES-inspired platformers, imho.

Now that the Up-Armored Edition has been released I figure it's a good time to review this. I've got about 70 hours in the game so far and don't see myself qutting any time soon.

Do you want to play a tank with a cloaking field and invisibly drive over your opponents? Do you want to be a multi-story mech bristling with lasers that wins through sheer firepower? Or maybe an agile anti-grav making hit and run attacks with corrossive chemical weapons? The huge amount of vehicles and weapons means you can play however you want. Huge levels with 100% destructible terrain mean you can carve your own path through the game, either through brute force or stealth.

There's also a ton of difficulty settings in Freelance mode in the form of pilots, each of which has a difficulty rating that is either stable or goes up steadily over multiple levels. In addition you can adjust the game speed in the menus to make things less hectic.

There's been multiple times I've broken out laughing during this game as I suddenly realize the absolute massive damage that's been done to the city during a fight. Though it might not seem like this game has much of a story, the info logs set up a surpisingly deep and darkly satiric setting. For example, you get extra pay for collateral damage. A civilian casualty is worth $50. A decorative shrub is $100.

Also worth mentioning is that the dev support has been incredible post release. There have been multiple updates including weapon rebalances to make sure everything in the game feels fun to use. 

The controls may take a bit of getting used to if you aren't familiar with tank controls (however there are multiple control settings available). But once you do this game has a huge amount of entertaining content. I can't recommend this enough.

32232003.review:
This may be the only game I regret getting from the Humble Monthly Bundle pack, and not knowing about it before then. I had never seen a single image of this game or of its indev version Matador. I had not seen this on my Steam reccomended list, curators list, or on RPS. I wasn't scouring, but still. I regret getting this in a bundle, because I know I'd have purchased this the moment I saw it at $20, and I would've bought it sooner then that at the current $14. 

Brigador is almost a simple concept; you are a mercenary pilot, and your contract is to topple a South American style dictatorship on a far off colony world. You pilot a mech walker, tanks, tiny power-suits, and even anti-gravity tanks [all in three distinct enough factions]. The weapons feel very real, the controls are incredibly solid, and the combat is incredibly refreshing and difficult. For anyone who fell in love with C&C games like Red Alert or especially Tiberian Sun, they will be visibly aroused by the graphics. The description by devs that this is a 'Kool-Aid man simulator' is remarkably applicable, as the best tactic is often to rush through an apartment block flanking your foe.

I am not even finished with the campaign, of which there are literally a dozen tutorial levels that actually have meat, and two dozen actually missions with 4 different starting configuartions each to complete. You earn money, and funnel that back into puchasing pilots and gear to use in Operations, something almost akin to Diablos dungeons. You can purchase packs of anywhere from 2 to 20+ levels to run through any pilot configuration you choose, earning money based on how difficult you've made it for yourself. That makes for a very nice feedback loop, much nicer then, say, Diablos. You earn only pride for beating a Hell level run with a shitty motorcycle, but you crave that pride. Like starting a Dwarf Fortress map on a glacier, just because.

Another aspect I find absolutely incredible is the dev team. For a small team to place this much effort, polish, and obvious enthusiasm into a $20 package, rather then a watered down $40-$60 game with in-game purchases and DLC level packs gallore. This is an incredible amount of game for the money. Not to mention how responsive to community I have seen them be. Two separate devs came to answer an angry thread about a particularily tricky level, and both took a lot of time to explain as best they could to the player, but also preserving the experience. They didn't say "Yeah theres a command we use to skip levels...". To take the time out of their day like that as a developer is unique. Assasins Creed devs don't do tech support. 

All in all I highly reccomend this game to several people; Mech enthusiasts, C&C junkies, lovers of strategy, lovers of finely crafted menus and UI's, and fans of Just Cause. Just cause they're pretty similar with the dictator thing.

12/10, cannot wait to see what this team does next.

搭乗者の物語がない。
二足よりホバーの方が有利すぎると感じた。
回避能力に長けているし、特殊兵器を使いこなせば立ち回りもスムーズ。
二足の良さを感じにくい。
爆発物との判別がしづらく、一部の目標となる対象物が見つけづらい(守備兵等)。
ミッションの種類が少ない。
協力プレイができない。
マップが少々広い。
